I.  THE ENSUING PROJECT 
 
1.  The ensuing project Uzbekistan: Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation Corridor 2 
(Bukhara–Miskin–Urgench–Khiva) Railway Electrification Project, scheduled for commitment in 
2021,  targets  the  region  of  Khorezm  in  western  Uzbekistan.  The  project  will  electrify  and 
modernize the 465 kilometers railway line between Bukhara, Miskin, Urgench, and Khiva. The 
electrification of the railway will significantly reduce the temporal distance of Khorezm to other 
urbanized areas of Uzbekistan and facilitate transport of agricultural goods and increase trade of 
its industrial assets. It will support industrial development and economic growth, especially in 
higher value-added sectors such as tourism, as the region is home to Khiva, accredited as a world 
heritage site by the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization. This, in turn, 
will facilitate employment generation for the locals, including women. The project’s stated impact 
is “sustainable regional trade and economic activity promoted along Central Asia Regional 
Economic Cooperation Corridor 2.” The project’s targeted outcome is improved railway services 
for freight and passengers in Western Uzbekistan. The project consists of two outputs: (i) “railway 
infrastructure along the Bukhara–Miskin–Urgench–Khiva line upgraded” and (ii) “tourism corridor 
Bukhara–Miskin–Urgench–Khiva developed.”  
 
2.  The project is estimated to cost $439.00 million. Of this amount, $162.00 million will be 
financed from the Asian Development Bank’s (ADB) Ordinary Capital Resources, $108.00 million 
will be cofinanced by the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank and $169.00 million from the 
government. The project is included in the country operations business plan for Uzbekistan, 2020-
2022.1   
 
3.  The project is proposed to be categorized as effective gender mainstreaming (EGM). It  
includes gender targets in each of the two outputs in the design and monitoring framework: for 
output 1, “100 UTY staff, including 20 women staff, demonstrated knowledge and skills in 
operation and maintenance of high-speed railway lines” and for output 2 “number of tourists 
traveling by train along the corridor reaches 120,000 per annum, of which 50% are women” and 
“at least 75 train station workers, including 38 women apply knowledge and skills on tourism 
promotion and marketing (2020 Baseline: none).”2   
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE SUBPROJECT 
 
A.  Overall Progress of the Technical Assistance Cluster 
 
4.  The technical assistance cluster was approved on 8 April 2020 with an allocation of 
$3,000,000 and a target completion date of 31 December 2022. Subproject 1 was approved on 
15 April 2020 for $300,000, of which $250,000 is being financed on a grant basis by ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 6) and $50,000 from TASF-other sources.3 Its original 
target completion date is 31 December 2020. The target completion date was extended to 31 
January 2021.4 Subproject 1 has the following outputs: (i) semi-annual gender action plan 
updates of ongoing gender equity (GEN) and EGM projects and updates on gender actions of 
some gender elements (SGE) projects collected and enhanced; (ii) project completion reports of

B.  Subproject Scope 
 
5.  The subproject will support both the preparation and design of the ensuing project as well 
as its implementation. The subproject will contribute to and maximize the positive impact of the 
ensuing project on women.  It will build the capacities of women from the communities in the 
project area, particularly, (i) female students of science, technology, engineering, and math 
(STEM) and TVET courses to help them meet skills requirements for railway operations and 
management and (ii) women engaged in  the tourism and hospitality industry. 
 
6.  The subproject will help enhance the employability of female STEM and TVET students in 
technical positions by providing training on railway technology and management. The trainings 
will be designed based on the assessment of the curricula and content of STEM courses vis-à-
vis the skills requirements of UTY. The modules may also be utilized in the capacity building 
activities for UTY staff on railway operation and maintenance, as appropriate. The subproject will 
support women’s participation in the tourism and hospitality industry by providing women from the 
communities with trainings in tourism and hospitality-related learning programs and accreditation, 
as needed. Women who are currently working in or operating enterprises in the industry will be 
given priority for the trainings.5

D.  Subproject Cost and Financing 
 
8.  The TA subproject is estimated to cost $300,000, which will be financed on a grant basis 
by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 6). The key expenditure items are listed in 
Appendix 1. The government was informed that approval of the subproject does not commit ADB 
to finance any ensuing project. The procurement of consulting services will be in accordance with 
ADB Procurement Policy (2017 as amended from time to time) and associated staff instructions 
and/or project administration instructions.   
 
E.  Subproject Implementation Arrangements 
 
9.  ADB will administer the subproject. The Portfolio, Results, Safeguards, and Gender Unit 
in ADB’s Central and West Asia Department, and in close coordination with the Transport Division 
will  select,  supervise,  and  evaluate  consultants.  The  subproject  will  be  implemented  from 
December 2020 to November 2022.
